**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for actual and consequential damages or statutory damages of not less than one month’s rent, and may also be responsible for the tenant’s reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

**G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3**.proposition: Venue and jurisdiction are proper in the **Boston Housing Court Department** pursuant to **G.L. c. 185C, § 3**, because the premises are located within the city of Boston and the cause of action arises from a tenancy in that jurisdiction.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every lease or tenancy at will under Massachusetts law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly describes the "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment owed by the landlord and treats it as an existing, background obligation in the landlord-tenant relationship, without suggesting it is limited to particular kinds of leases. The court discusses constructive eviction as a breach of this implied covenant, citing prior Massachusetts cases applying the same principle, which reflects the understanding that quiet enjoyment is an implied covenant in Massachusetts leases generally. However, the case does not expressly state in so many words that the covenant is implied in "every" lease or tenancy at will, so that part of the proposition is inferred rather than directly quoted.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.relevant_excerpt:
The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge. The landlords do not challenge the judge’s conclusion that the noise emanating from the lounge was sufficient to constitute a constructive eviction, if that noise could be attributed to the landlords.

Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every lease or tenancy at will under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes quiet enjoyment as a standard landlord-tenant concept and then states that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment. It does so in general terms, not limited to written leases, and explicitly references “tenancy at will” earlier in quoting the statute, indicating the covenant is implied in any tenancy relationship under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, **41.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, **417 Mass. 273** (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, **41.proposition: A landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s failure to act allows a condition on the property to substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, **41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, **41.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses when a landlord’s omissions can breach the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court states that quiet enjoyment protects against serious interference caused by what the landlord “failed to do,” and holds that if the landlord’s inaction allows unlawful activity to persist in common areas so that tenants lose their use of those areas, that condition can “seriously interfere” with the tenancy and “substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.” This aligns with the proposition that a landlord’s failure to act, allowing a harmful condition to continue, can breach the covenant.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, **41.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies… and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, **266 Mass.proposition: A landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s failure to act allows a condition on the property to substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, **266 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses an implied covenant that the landlord will refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and it finds liability based on affirmative remodeling activities authorized by the landlord. It does not address landlord liability for a mere failure to act or omission that allows a harmful condition to persist. Because the proposition is framed in terms of the landlord’s failure to act, while Winchester concerns affirmative acts and authorized work, the case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, **266 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially "impair the character and value of the leased premises." Brande v. Grace, supra, page 212. 
...
It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants, and that when the bill was filed further interference was threatened.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847**.proposition: Persistent water leaks, dampness, and mold constitute substantial interferences with the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the premises.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847**.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a statutory violation of the lead paint laws, by itself, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it holds that at least negligent conduct and landlord notice are required. The only references to conditions like water leaks or dampness appear indirectly through citations to other cases (e.g., Simon v. Solomon; Darmetko) and not as part of this case’s own holding. Thus, this decision does not itself establish that persistent water leaks, dampness, and mold are substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment, even though it cites other cases that do so.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847**.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

*Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Dav.raw_text: *Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Davis*, **29 Mass. App. Ct. 9** (1990)
*Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Dav.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes “interference” within the meaning of **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, as interpreted in *Blackett v. Olanoff*, supra, and *Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Davis*, **29 Mass. App. Ct. 9** (1990).
*Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Dav.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about a Terry-type stop, transportation of a suspect for a showup identification, suggestiveness of the identification, jury instructions, and ineffective assistance of counsel. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or the concept of ‘interference’ with quiet enjoyment as interpreted in Blackett v. Olanoff. The citation given (Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Davis, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 9 (1990)) is to an entirely different case than the robbery-identification decision reproduced here, so this text cannot support the claimed proposition about interference under § 14.
*Habit Management Institute, Inc. v. Dav.relevant_excerpt:
We affirm the convictions.

1. Detention and transportation of the defendant to the scene of the robbery.
… The principal issue raised in this case is whether the police, after subjecting the defendant to a Terry-type stop, were justified in taking him back a short distance to the scene of the crime for purposes of a prompt identification.

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, **417 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s continued neglect and dismissal of Plaintiff’s complaints, after repeated notice, constitutes willful or knowing interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, **417 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion deals almost entirely with the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and related issues in the Section 8 context, not with the standard for willful or knowing interference with quiet enjoyment. Although the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the Supreme Judicial Court does not describe the landlord’s conduct in terms of ‘willful or knowing’ interference or analyze the elements of that claim; it merely notes that no separate damages were awarded to avoid duplication. Thus, the case does not establish the proposition that continued neglect after notice constitutes willful or knowing interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, **417 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, **3.proposition: In addition to the statutory violation, these conditions breach the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363 Mass. 184** (1973), and form the factual basis for the statutory claim under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, **3.support_reasoning:
This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent, not the majority, and he explicitly criticizes and narrows the majority’s implied warranty of habitability, preferring to tie landlord obligations strictly to statutory and code requirements. While he agrees that statutory minimum standards create obligations enforceable by tenants and that noncompliance can affect rent liability, he does not embrace a broad, freestanding implied warranty as the majority does, nor does he link it specifically to G.L. c. 186, § 14. Thus, this portion of the opinion does not itself support the stated proposition, which relies on the majority’s broader recognition of an implied warranty.

The majority opinion in Hemingway does recognize an implied warranty of habitability, but that text is not what is quoted here; relying on this concurring/dissenting passage alone to support the proposition is inaccurate.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, **3.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. … I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule…”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.proposition: Under *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855** (1991), a landlord is strictly liable under § 14 for any act or omission that substantially interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, even if motivated by negligence rather than malice.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Gonzalez discusses multiple landlord‑tenant theories, including G.L. c. 186, § 14 (quiet enjoyment), but it does not articulate any rule that landlords are strictly liable under § 14 for any substantial interference regardless of malice or negligence. The court’s detailed analysis in this excerpt focuses on c. 93A and emotional distress, not on defining the standard of liability under § 14, and the quiet enjoyment claim is mentioned only in passing without elaboration on the mental state required. Therefore, this case does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.relevant_excerpt: After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action in the Housing Court for the city of Boston for nonpayment of rent, the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); (3) negligent failure to maintain the premises; (4) intentional infliction of emotional distress; (5) retaliation in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 18; and (6) violations of G.L.c. 93A. After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims...
